Award.AwardTitle: Copper Triangle Pilot Project: Enhancing Opportunities for Geoscience Studies and Careers in a Culturally Diverse, Underserved Rural Mining Area
Award.AbstractNarration: The Copper Triangle Pilot Project (CTPP) is a partnership among Arizona State University, Central Arizona College, a rural high-need school district (Superior Unified School District) and local industry (Resolution Copper Mining Company) to develop a research-based, sustainable pathway to baccalaureate degrees and careers in the Earth and environmental sciences for underrepresented minority students (mostly Hispanic and Native American) who reside in an underserved rural mining area (the "Copper Triangle") of central Arizona. CTPP is directed toward a type of geographic and demographic region not commonly served by other programs to promote equity and diversity: a rural community with a population that is more than 50% underrepresented minorities, and historically dependent on the extraction of natural resources. The interlinked components of CTPP, informed by current research on the most effective practices for minority-student recruitment and retention in the Earth sciences comprise an effective stakeholder partnership, concurrent-enrollment college courses, place-based instruction, a smoothly articulated academic program from high school to the B.S. and B.A., regional summer STEM internships, mentoring and support, and embedded teacher professional development. The Earth science curriculum is richly place-based (situated in Southwest landscapes, geologic phenomena, resources, and environmental issues) and informed by the diverse cultures and history of the local community. Each component is formatively and summatively assessed using mixed methods. The project has received strong endorsement and support from all community stakeholders and will be sustained into the future with regularly scheduled course offerings, continued support by the mining firm, and by the economic diversification and growth of the community and region catalyzed by the new mine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Copper Triangle Pilot Project (CTPP) was a partnership to effect change in the underserved rural mining area (“Copper Triangle”) of Central Arizona, which is a type of geographic and demographic region rarely served by other programs to promote equity and diversity. CTPP encompassed a research university (Arizona State University), community-college district (Central Arizona College), a regional career and technical education district (Cobre Valley Institute of Technology), several rural high-need school districts (Superior, Miami, Globe, Ray, Winkleman, and San Carlos), and local industry (Resolution Copper Mining Company). Intellectual Merit: CTPP was designed to develop a research-based and sustainable pathway to college degrees and careers in the Earth and environmental sciences for underrepresented, mostly Hispanic and Native American students in the Copper Triangle. The CTPP partners instituted a place-based, culturally responsive program of dual-enrollment community-college geology courses and summer university research internships for local high-school students, and a professional-development course and program in geoscience for their teachers that operated from 2011 to 2015. The curricula and articulation pathways are solidly in place, although continuation of the program beyond the grant period has been postponed by slow socioeconomic development in the region. Broader Impacts: CTPP served student cohorts that were minority-majority and facilitated progress to college degrees and careers for many participants. A cadre of teachers in the participating school districts also received professional training and continuing education credit in Southwest-based geoscience. All members of the CTPP partnership remain committed and in regular communication while working to establish a sustainable source of funds to reinstate the program.
